 French Economic Growth Slowed in 1Q
 
 By Associated Press
 
 May 20, 2005, 6:19 AM EDT
 
 PARIS -- Growth in the French economy slowed sharply in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter of 2004 as consumer spending sagged, the national statistics institute Insee said Friday.
 
 In a preliminary estimate, Insee said first-quarter gross domestic product growth was 0.2 percent, well below the 0.5 percent increase forecast by economists. (U.S. is 4.4%)
 
 The new data suggests that French growth is well below the pace needed to deliver the 2 percent to 2.5 percent expansion targeted by the government this year as it struggles to bring down its public deficit and unemployment, currently at a five-year high of 10.2 percent.
 
 Even before Friday's disappointing data, most economists believed growth was unlikely to be much above 1.8 percent in 2005.
 
 "In these conditions, French growth won't be 2.5 percent or 2 percent this year, but around 1.6 percent," said Marc Touati, chief economist at Natexis Banques Populaires.
 
 "Considering that employment stagnated last year with 2.1 percent economic growth, it's not a GDP expansion of 1.6 percent that will change things this year."
 
 Insee has changed its base year to 2000 from 1995 since it last published quarterly data. That brought changes to estimates for 2004, which combined to put full-year growth at 2.1 percent, down from the 2.4 percent it previously estimated.
 
 Fourth-quarter GDP growth was 0.7 percent from the previous quarter, Insee said, rather than the 0.9 percent it estimated previously.
 
 Consumer spending growth also slowed in the first quarter to 0.7 percent, Insee said, from 1.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 2004, and French exports contracted 0.1 percent after a 0.9 percent expansion.
 
 Consumer spending remained solid through 2004, helping the euro zone's second-biggest economy to outperform its neighbors Germany and Italy.
 
 But observers have been warning for some time that stubbornly high unemployment would undermine consumer confidence and ultimately spending as the French take to topping up savings in uncertain times.

From the perspective of long-term productivity growth, the U.S. couldn't be much healthier.
 
 Which is more important, big trade deficits or high productivity? For now it looks as if productivity wins. Why? The net wealth of the U.S. is huge compared to 10 years ago, even after taking into account that Americans owe foreigners some $3 trillion because of cumulative trade gaps. Rising net wealth means the positive influence of higher productivity -- which boosts economic output -- has been stronger than the negative impact of big trade deficits.
 
 Think about it this way: The U.S. is like a family enjoying rising income even as it takes on sizable debt -- not too unusual in these days of big mortgages. You'd worry if such a family had to sell off assets or draw down savings to pay for today's consumption, a sign that it was living beyond its means. The family would soon be in trouble if it didn't curtail spending. But if the family's net worth -- assets minus debt -- is going up, its financial position is actually improving.
 
 That's essentially what's happening to the financial position of the U.S.: Not only is it getting better, it's getting a lot better. The best way to show this is to look at a new measure of national wealth that I call "net real wealth per capita." Start with the net worth of households as reported by the Federal Reserve. Then subtract federal, state, and local debt, and adjust for inflation and changes in population. What's left is a figure that measures, somewhat imperfectly, the average net value of the liabilities and assets of Americans, assuming that they are responsible for the government's debt as well as their own.
 
 By this measure, net real wealth per person is up 16% since the end of 2002. While it's still a bit below the all-time high reached in early 2000, over the past 10 years it has risen 57%. That's one of the biggest 10-year rises on record, beaten only by the decade ending in 1999.
